in2011.http

Class Message

  • java.lang.Object
    • in2011.http.Message
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    RequestMessage, ResponseMessage

    public abstract class Message
extends Object
    The part of an HTTP message before the message body. This is an abstract class; client code will typically use the two concrete subclasses RequestMessage and ResponseMessage to parse and represent HTTP request and response messages.

      • addHeaderField

        public void addHeaderField(String fieldName,
                  String value)
        Add a new header field. The new value will overwrite any existing value if this message already has a header field with the given name.
        Parameters:
        fieldName - the field name.
        value - the field value.

      • getHeaderFieldValue

        public String getHeaderFieldValue(String fieldName)
        The value of a field in this message.
        Parameters:
        fieldName - the field name.
        Returns:
        the value of the named field in the header for this message, or null if this message does not contain such a field.

      • readLine

        protected static String readLine(InputStream is)
                          throws IOException,
                                 MessageFormatException,
                                 UnexpectedEndOfSequenceException
        Read the next line of text from an input stream. Note that RFC 2616 specifies CRLF as the line terminator but also recommends that LF should be tolerated, which is what this method does. This method does not close the input stream.
        Parameters:
        is - the input stream from which a line is read.
        Returns:
        the line read, minus the line terminator.
        Throws:
        UnexpectedEndOfStreamException - if the stream is empty
        MessageFormatException - if the input stream is non-empty but no line terminator is found
        IOException
        UnexpectedEndOfSequenceException

      • readFirstLine

        protected static String readFirstLine(InputStream is)
                               throws IOException,
                                      MessageFormatException
        Read the first line of an HTTP message from an input stream. Leading empty lines are tolerated and discarded; the first non-empty line is returned.
        Parameters:
        is - the input stream from which a line is read.
        Returns:
        the line read, minus the line terminator.
        Throws:
        IOException
        EmptyMessageException - if the stream is empty or contains only empty lines
        MessageFormatException - if the first (and only) non-empty line has no line terminator

      • parseHeaderFields

        protected void parseHeaderFields(InputStream is)
                          throws IOException,
                                 MessageFormatException
        Read header fields from an input stream and add them to the message. Header fields are read repeatedly from the input stream and added to the message until an empty line is read. This method assumes each field is on a separate line; it makes no attempt to support folding of field values over multiple lines (RFC 2616 Section 2.2). The field names and values are not validated in any way; any line of the form NAME : VALUE is recognised as a header field; leading and trailing whitespace around field names and values is discarded.
        Parameters:
        is - the input stream from which to read header fields.
        Throws:
        MessageFormatException - if no empty line is found or if any of the lines read do not have the form NAME : VALUE.
        IOException

      • parseVersion

        protected static String parseVersion(String v)
                              throws MessageFormatException
        Parse a string as an HTTP version string.
        Parameters:
        v - the string to be parsed.
        Returns:
        the significant part of the string (the part after the leading HTTP/)
        Throws:
        MessageFormatException - if the given string is not a valid HTTP version string.
